summary: This week we're sharing a series called Ted Connects Community and Hope. Some very timely conversations with Ted Speakers around the coronavirus pandemic. This one features Gary Liu, CEO of the South China Morning Post in a virtual conversation

This is a virtual Ted team scattered around New York, currently one of the epicenters of this pandemic. We watched the situation in China quickly worsen and in the most recent weeks dramatically improve. There are a lot of lessons we can learn from what China experienced and how they responded

CNN's John Defterios is in Hong Kong and working from home. He says he's self-quarantine because of a confirmed case in his workplace. He and his wife were back in the United States when Hong Kong got its first confirmed case

New York is at home, New York City is athome. So we certainly empathize with what you guys are dealing with right now and going through in the city. And we are seeing our friends and our family back home in New York and California and checking in on them, trying
Wuhan itself, which was the where the pandemic started was the first epicenter and the major epicenter. Wuhan is opening up in April 8th

The World Health Organization is struggling with the definition of what is a confirmed case, what is an infection is different from country to country. As an example in China, the folks that have tested positive but are asymptomatic, we understand now that they are not included since February 7

The first part was discovery and a lot of denial and then there was this two and a half month period of response and containment. We are in the third phase that I would call recovery and rehabilitation, rehabilitation being the rehabilitation of China's image

The first time we heard about the coronavirus, this mysterious respiratory disease that looked somewhat like SARS was on December 30th. That was the day that there's a doctor that is now, his name is known all over the world for the unfortunate reason that he ended up eventually

On January 20th, he visited Wuhan, and he admitted for the first time that human to human transmission was possible. And so, of course, the course of action, not only in China, but also all over the world started to change

On March 10th, Xi Jinping's visit to Wuhan kind of signaled the worst is over, and then they moved into the recovery and rehabilitation phase. So, if I'm hearing correctly, thank you, and thank you for sharing all of that

The Chinese New Year holiday is the largest human migration that happens on Earth. About 400 million people travel during about a 40-day period that would have started on January 24th. Wuhan is one of the key transportation hubs of the country

The first case of SARS-like pneumonia was reported to the World Health Organization on November 17. It was only a couple of weeks before officials realized that there was a pneumonia going around. The government has over the course of the last several weeks been cracking down on information

Wuhan police have apologized to Dr. Lee's family, and they have actually been a couple of police policemen have been punished in Wuhan for the way that they handled the situation. I can tell you from Hong Kong's point of view, without the open sharing of information

Wuhan and Hubei are the last places that are so shut down with Wuhan being the city that is shut down until April 8th. Hong Kong has actually gone back into a second wave of social isolation and distancing

Hong Kong is starting to see a second wave of infections. But for us, honestly, it's the first time that we've had a spike. And it's because of important cases. It's because a lot of Hong Kong residents who left are now returning

In Hong Kong, everyone wears masks. 90% of Hong Kongers during SARS wore masks. New health alert systems, warnings and treatment protocols put in place. New channels of communication and data and information exchange were opened up

Hong Kong is famous for its dim sum. The dim sum carts, which are also a very popular in New York, Chinatown as an example, went away after SARS. Most dim sum restaurants that you'll go to in Hong Kong now, the vast majority of them, you have

Hong Kong was able to react really, really fast to the SARS outbreak. The entire city reacted and went into this mode where you wore masks, you washed your hands, you carried hand sanitizers, you stopped going to public places

I think communication is a huge deal. A lot of corporates have done an incredible job in Hong Kong and communicating very transparently with their employees. Insurance companies have also been making it actually quite easy for people to understand how to get tested
The SARS scare has made testing in China and Hong Kong more effective. But point of care testing still doesn't exist in volume in the US. So they have to save these tests

Everyone knows that if somebody that you've been in contact with test positive, you're going to be called in by the hospital authorities. The triage system then becomes overflowing. Whereas here, generally speaking, everyone can get tested

The shutdown of Hu Bay province certainly helped. The major cities actually went into isolation and quarantine as well. China is very prepared for this because the technology stack in China, including consumer side services

Some of the scenes from there were horrifying, but there were amazing stories as well. What should we learn from what happened there? Well, it started off horrifying. There was not that much information
Two massive hospitals with thousands of beds of capacity were built within 10 days. Those were the triage units for those who have very mild symptoms. But then the capacity actually ramped up

I have every confidence that the US health care system is going to be able to respond well. I have many, many friends who are medical professionals in the United States. So I have full trust in the system and the people that man those systems out of capacity

SARS seems to have acted as its own kind of vaccine. It's because of the social memory of SARS that has meant people are a little bit more selfless and I just said, okay, I will stay home because I might have come in contact

Running a news organization in the moment like they're so close to the initial epicenter and where the outbreak started is complicated. Most of our senior editors and certainly the most senior editors are editor in chief on mass head leadership. They were all journalists and there were reporters during SARS

We did send people to Wuhan early on in January. We also had reporters there right before the lockdown. After the lockdown, we were lucky enough to pull all of them out. But we actually did change very quickly the way that we report

There's been a lot of instances of really interesting censorship, but also more interestingly how the Chinese citizens have fought that censorship and reacted to that censorship. The first one is is on education now schools have been shut down across China for quite some time now. And I do think that there

The idea of working remotely is not much of a concept in China and across most of ages certainly far less than in the United States and I'm from the US tech industry so it was pretty normal. Online education very, very quickly moved online and part of that move online was that courses

There's hope that this whole thing because it's a common enemy for the world will actually bring the world together in some ways but I'm curious how you think about this like President Trump has started to referring to this as the Chinese virus. I think one one thing that is still really

Chris Cuomo: "I just really want to be an optimist Chris but I think that everything we see especially the data it shows that it is going to get far worse that before it gets better" "I'm very fearful for what's going on the United States it's because of
